vmassol - (09:56): tmortagne: could it be possible that the template name passed to the Velocity Engine is used by Velocity as a key to cache macros? (I'm checking the velocity code but it's not very easy to follow it)

vmassol - (10:05): I've been wanting a check for some time:  
vmassol - (10:05): when someone hits saves and no changes has been done then don't save it  
vmassol - (10:05): (either wiki editor or wysiwyg editor)  
mflorea - (10:08): that's just a use case. but macros are changed when you type somewhere in a text, so without editing the macros. Preventing save when there are no changes still doesn't stop "side effects" like "= Title" being transformed into "= Title =" and I don't think we can fix this. It's somehow normal.  
mflorea - (10:08): when you save from WYSIWYG, the content is "normalized"  
vmassol - (10:10): yes I know about normalization  
mflorea - (10:10): vmassol: IMO we have to accept this. otherwise we need to send additional information to the client to preserve the form of the wiki syntax  
vmassol - (10:10): the question is whether we still want changes to appear even if the user has not made any change at all  
vmassol - (10:11): couldn't we do this:  
vmassol - (10:11): - take the initial content, normalize it  
vmassol - (10:11): - compare with the content modified by the user  
mflorea - (10:11): we could  
vmassol - (10:12): note: it requires in memory twice the space required to fit one page  
arkub joined #xwiki at 10:12  
mflorea - (10:12): but if the user has just fixed a typo, she/he would still see lots of other changes, due to normalization  
vmassol - (10:12): mflorea: yes that's a pb too  
vmassol - (10:13): maybe  
vmassol - (10:13): we could normalize on wiki edit save  
vmassol - (10:13): that would solve it  
vmassol - (10:13): ie we always have normalized content  
vmassol - (10:14): tmortagne: wdyt?  
mflorea - (10:14): yes, but might annoy some wiki syntax users, because they have their own "style" which is lost when they save the page  
vmassol - (10:14): I remember we talked about this with tmortagne a long time ago actually  
vmassol - (10:14): mflorea: actually there's only 1 style  
vmassol - (10:15): so it's not a matter of style  
vmassol - (10:15): IMO  
vmassol - (10:15): what the parser does it support some wrong styles  
vmassol - (10:15): and fixes them  
vmassol - (10:15): s/it/is/

mflorea - (10:16): writing {{macro}}content{{/macro}} versus {{macro}}]\ncontent\n{{/macro}} can be viewed as a style option  
mflorea - (10:18): I'm +1 for normalizing the content on save btw :)  
vmassol - (10:18): let's see what tmortagne thinks too  
mflorea - (10:19): ok  
vmassol - (10:19): it would make sense  
vmassol - (10:19): IMO  
vmassol - (10:19): so the wiki editor and wysiwyg editor will have the same behavior  
mflorea - (10:19): hmm, what about save&continue?

vmassol - (10:20): tmortagne: the second problem is not a problem for xwiki 2.0 syntax  
vmassol - (10:21): for the first problem, we need to decide  
mflorea - (10:21): on save&continue we would need to reset the content of the wiki editor text area, which can mean loosing the current caret position  
vmassol - (10:21): but if we agree that there's only one style  
tmortagne - (10:21): vmassol: sure but anyway IMO it's ùmore work to do at save time which is useless  
vmassol - (10:21): then it's normal  
tmortagne - (10:21): so i don't like it very much  
vmassol - (10:21): otherwise the wysiwyg editor shouldn't change the style eitehr  
vmassol - (10:21): it's not logical  
vmassol - (10:21): we don't support custom styles in the rendering  
vmassol - (10:21): there's only 1 style supported right now  
tmortagne - (10:24): i still feel it's a useless work done at save time, users will more and more use WYSIWYG and wiki mode will mostly be used when you have a velocity macro around the whole content or things like that and in that case nothing is normalize inside macros  
vmassol - (10:25): tmortagne: I'm fine to choose whatever strategy but it needs to be the same both editors  
vmassol - (10:25): we cannot have the wysiwyg editor perform normalization when the wiki editor deson't do it  
vmassol - (10:25): or vice-versa  
tmortagne - (10:25): the WYSIWYG doe snot not do any normalization on pupose  
tmortagne - (10:25): it convert html -> xwiki/2.0  
vmassol - (10:25): I know  
vmassol - (10:26): but from the user pov that's called normalization  
tmortagne - (10:26): and i really don't see why "we cannot have the wysiwyg editor perform normalization when the wiki editor deson't do it"  
vmassol - (10:26): well it seems obvious to me  
vmassol - (10:26): the reason why I've just brought this topic for ex  
tmortagne - (10:26): user ill really don't understand that the content he written in wiki editor changed  
vmassol - (10:26): I'm a tech user  
vmassol - (10:27): I create content in wiki mode  
vmassol - (10:27): I pay attention to my style  
vmassol - (10:27): then someone edits the page in wyswig mode  
vmassol - (10:27): and breaks all my styles!  
tmortagne - (10:27): maybe default style is not good enough  
vmassol - (10:27): again see http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/DevGuide/GroovyClassHelloWorldTutorial?viewer=changes  
vmassol - (10:27): the guys has not touched a single line

vmassol - (10:28): it would be hard to see it  
tmortagne - (10:28): since there is no change  
vmassol - (10:28): since it's mixed with normalization changes  
tmortagne - (10:28): it's because when you do bsolutely nothing the document is still saved

vmassol - (10:29): we talked about it with marius above

vmassol - (10:32): since it means saving extra information about the user style  
vmassol - (10:32): which we don't support

vmassol - (10:32): IMO it's ok if we explain that the xwiki syntax 2.0 has only one syntax  
vmassol - (10:33): of course I'd also prefer the other solution to keep the user style but that's hard to do  
tmortagne - (10:33): there is also another minus: it makes the page more fragile because it means if there is any bug in xwiki/2.0 renderer you will never be able to put the content you wanted even if you don't need xwiki/2.0 renderer since you provide the source  
tmortagne - (10:36): i would really prefer having a way to be able to put the real unmodified source, it's also need simply when i want to test something with the xwiki/2.0 parser  
tmortagne - (10:36): if we normalize by default it should be possible to save without normalizing IMO

tmortagne - (10:42): i don't see the "WYSIWYG has limitations lets apply the same limitations everywhere" as a good thing to do  
vmassol - (10:43): tmortagne: sure, but it's not the wysiwyg it's the rendering engine which has this limitation  
vmassol - (10:43): do you have a proposal for the rendering engine to remove this limitation?  
vmassol - (10:43): (we talked about it briefly in the past but not in great details)  
vmassol - (10:43): (and it sounded complex)  
tmortagne - (10:43): vmassol: it doe snot have any limitation whe you provide the source  
tmortagne - (10:44): from user POV the limitation is on the WYSIWYG  
vmassol - (10:44): yes  
vmassol - (10:44): but technically to solve it we need to the renderers to know about positional stuff  
vmassol - (10:44): s/to the/the+  
tmortagne - (10:46): we need parser to provide about positional stuff anyway for many use case but that's not the tricky part, the tricky part is to not loose this information in the WYSIWYG IMO  
tmortagne - (10:46): and i think it would make the WYSIWYG way too complex  
tmortagne - (10:48): plus doing thing based on positional stuff is pretty much impossible when you go to another syntax and so modification  
tmortagne - (10:48): it doe snot make sense to have xwiki/2.0 syntax positions in the XHTML  
tmortagne - (10:49): s/so modification/do modification/  
tmortagne - (10:50): IMO it's impossible to support custom formatting in WYSIWYG if we want to keep it clean and generic (i.e. not knowing about xwiki/2.0 syntax details)  
tmortagne - (10:52): but again i really don't see major issue on WYSIWYG and Wiki editor not doing exactly the same thing  
tmortagne - (10:52): complex custom formatting is generally more inside macro like velocity  
tmortagne - (10:54): with pure wiki macro i don't thing you want that much special formatting  
tmortagne - (10:54): and if the default formating  of some thing like lists are not good we can change it i think  
mflorea - (10:57): I agree with tmortagne re WYSIWYG and rendering complexity and I don't think it would bring much value to be able to keep the style when editing in WYSIWYG mode. It would be nice though to be able to normalize the wiki editor content, maybe not by default, but as an option. We could even have a shortcut like Ctrl+F (in Eclipse) to normalize the content while editing.
